clues: Born in Ohio’s fifth most populous city.
Has played professionally in both Florida and California.
Shares a nickname with European royalty.
Passed a record held for nearly four decades.
Made his professional debut the same year Finding Nemo was released.
funFact: He appeared on the cover of Sports Illustrated before playing a single NBA game.

clues: Won her first major singles title before turning 18.
Has a sibling who also competed professionally at the highest level.
Returned to win a major title after becoming a mother.
Known for a dominant serve and distinctive fashion on the court.
Her 23 Grand Slam titles are the most by any player in the Open Era.
funFact: She won her first U.S. Open in 1999 while still a teenager.

clues: Drafted after 198 players had already been selected.
Spent most of his career under the same head coach.
Known for late-game heroics and comeback wins.
Retired with more Super Bowl wins than any single franchise.
Famously associated with the number 12 jersey.
funFact: He was also drafted by a Major League Baseball team before committing to football.

clues: First appeared on the Olympic stage before turning 16.
Trained in a city not typically associated with swimming success.
Once stood on the podium while his national anthem played eight times in one Games.
Wore a distinctive warm-up outfit and famously intense expression before races.
Holds more gold than any single athlete in modern Olympic history.
funFact: His signature pre-race routine includes slapping his back and stretching with exaggerated arm swings—a habit since childhood.

clues: Left his home country as a teenager to pursue his career.
Spent over two decades at the same European club.
Known for his short stature and precise left foot.
Won a long-coveted international title late in his career.
Often compared to Diego Maradona.
funFact: He holds the record for most Ballon d'Or wins in history.

clues: Adapted from a novel that outsold Love Story the year it was published.
Its production was so controversial that real-life figures tried to influence the script.
Known for muting violence with classical music and slow pacing.
Famously features oranges as a recurring visual motif before acts of violence.
Ends with a symbolic transition of power behind a closed door.
funFact: The word “mafia” was only spoken once in the entire film due to pressure from Italian-American organizations.

clues: Blends the profane and profound without warning.
Elevates banter into existential monologue.
Features lives shaped by both bullets and breakfast.
Treats the sacred and the absurd with equal weight.
Its title hints at something cheap, pulpy—and poetic.
funFact: Despite its reputation for grit, the film’s most explosive moments often occur during quiet conversation.

clues: The sun always rises where the script says it should.
Comfort is weaponized in the name of control.
Surveillance wears a smile and a product pitch.
Escape begins not with a plan, but with doubt.
One man walks through the wall that was his world.
funFact: A real psychological condition was named after this film, describing patients convinced their lives are secretly being broadcast.

clues: Its story revolves around two families linked by architecture and labor.
Won top prizes at both Cannes and the Academy Awards.
Features a secret underground location central to the plot.
Deals with themes of class division and invisible boundaries.
In one scene, a flood leads to the revelation of something buried—both literally and metaphorically.
funFact: It became the first non-English-language film to win the Academy Award for Best Picture.

clues: Set in a city where loyalty and longing both change with the weather.
A place of temporary stays, permanent memories, and lost causes.
The piano knows more about the past than the people playing it.
Sacrifice arrives not as a choice, but as a necessity.
Ends with two men walking into fog, with war behind them and something new ahead.
funFact: Despite its timeless reputation, the film was written and rewritten even as it was being shot—sometimes with no ending in sight.

clues: Once praised as a hero of the commoners
Defied orders not with words, but with movement
His end came in daylight, surrounded by men he once trusted
The aftermath reshaped leadership forever
History remembers his fall more than his rule
funFact: He was assassinated on the Ides of March by fellow senators, including his friend Brutus.

clues: Walked a path most couldn’t see, but many followed
She led without title, yet was called by a prophet’s name
Slipped through nets meant to catch her, time and again
Fought for freedom with no uniform
Her journeys were made in silence, but echoed loudly through time
funFact: She led hundreds of enslaved people to freedom via the Underground Railroad and later served as a Union spy.

clues: Grew from empty plates and heavy pockets
Its rallying cry outlived its leaders
Crowds cheered as heads rolled
Ideals clashed harder than armies
A stormed building became a symbol
funFact: The storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, is now celebrated as France's national holiday.

clues: Appeared quickly, but stayed long
Families waved across a border of concrete
Art and graffiti told stories the guards couldn’t stop
The line stood for more than geography
Its fall was louder than its construction
funFact: The Berlin Wall stood from 1961 to 1989, dividing East and West Berlin during the Cold War.

clues: Rewrote expectations while others read from scripts
Often stood where cameras weren’t focused
Spoke in columns more than speeches
Her legacy lives in documents, not monuments
Known more for action than ceremony
funFact: She was the first chair of the UN Commission on Human Rights and helped draft the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
